awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multi-instrumented, Two-Dimensional (2D) Studies of Equatorial Spread F
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop new observational capabilities by reactivating two instruments near the magnetic equator, a region which hosts a unique and puzzling set of phenomena in the near-Earth plasma environment. These phenomena range from large-scale plasma fountains that transport plasma away from the equator to small-scale disturbances in the plasma density that adversely affect satellite communication and navigation. The focus of the current investigation is on the equatorial spread F or ESF, a multi-scale plasma structure whose origins are poorly understood. This project will investigate generation of ESF by conducting two-dimensional, multi-instrumented observations of plasma conditions at the magnetic equatorial site of the Jicamarca Radio Observatory (JRO). This project will develop a better understanding of fundamental plasma processes including plasma instabilities and plasma-neutral coupling at low geomagnetic latitudes which are known to be a significant source of plasma disturbances that can disrupt radio communication channels. Further collaborative linkages between partner institutions in the US and an international partner (JRO) will be developed through this work. It will also promote teaching and stimulate integration of research and education by directly supporting one post-doctoral researcher and one graduate student, and by the Principal Investigator incorporating results from this research into classroom activities. 

The work will involve (1) a repair of a new radar system and airglow imager at JRO, (2) conducting 2D radio and optical observations of ESF at JRO, (3) ESF propagation analysis to determine whether F-region structures are generated locally or transported from another location, (4) comparing ESF occurrence and strength with plasma drift measurements to evaluate a hypothesis that post-midnight, quiet-time ESF can develop under conditions of weakening downward drifts, and (5) analysis of collocated radio and optical observations to study the causal relationship between large-scale plasma structures and ESF in the late-evening and post-midnight sectors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Equatorial spread F (ESF) is the name given, for historical reasons, to the manifestation of ionospheric electron density irregularities observed at low latitudes by a variety of instruments. We currently seek a better understanding of the physical mechanisms contributing to the morphology and day-to-day variability in the occurrence of ESF. ESF studies are also motivated by the impact of ionospheric irregularities on transionospheric radio signals such as those used by Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) (e.g., GPS).
 
Much of what we know about ESF has come from ground-based radar observations of echoes caused by ionospheric irregularities. Most of the radar observations of ESF, however, have been made using radars operating in the VHF frequency band (e.g., 50 MHz) which detect scatter from meter-scale irregularities. Additionally, these radar systems often made observations in a single direction (typically vertical) limiting our ability to track the genesis, development or decay of ESF events.
 
The project allowed us to devote efforts to repairing a UHF (445 MHz) radar system (AMISR-14) capable of electronic beam steering, making routine observations, and then using the observations to better understand ESF. AMISR-14 has been deployed at the Jicamarca Radio Observatory in Peru, a major facility of the Instituto Geofisico del Peru (IGP).  The project was carried out, in great part, by graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher with proper guidance and supervision of the PI. Therefore, the project contributed to scientific research as well as to the education and training of young scientists and engineers.
 
The project successfully repaired and operated AMISR-14 for over 3 years. The project also created an observational mode that produces two-dimensional (2D) views of ESF. Figure 1 from Rodrigues et al. (2023) shows an example of the 2D observations. The top panel shows the conventional Range-Time-Intensity (RTI) map generated with measurements made by a single antenna beam pointed near zenith. The top panels show images describing the distribution of sub-meter irregularities (UHF echoes) as a function of zonal (east-west) distance and height for different times. The temporal resolution of the images is 20 seconds. The sequence of images shows the vertical development of an ESF structure to the west of Jicamarca. Note that beam pointed vertically misses this event. The RTI map only shows weak echoes at lower altitudes.
 
These measurements allowed studies and advances related to the genesis of UHF ESF echoing structures caused by sub-meter irregularities under different geophysical conditions.  The project also helped a better understanding of the behavior of UHF echoes and this behavior compares with the behavior observed by a collocated VHF radar system. This is important for decisions related to the development of new ionospheric radar systems.
 
The project also supported and successfully trained two graduate (PhD) students and one postdoctoral researcher. Additionally, the project contributed by making a new radar system and measurements available to students participating in the research experience program of the Jicamarca Radio Observatory.

References:

Rodrigues, F.S., Milla, M.A., Scipion, D. et al. On new two-dimensional UHF radar observations of equatorial spread F at the Jicamarca Radio Observatory. Earth Planets Space 75, 120 (2023). https://doi.org/10.1186/s40623-023-01876-7
